content.data: üëã Welcome to Module 3! We've covered the what, how, and where of cloud computing. Now, it's time to dive into the core services that power the cloud. Today's focus is on Compute‚Äîthe raw processing power you use to run your applications.

content.title: ‚ö° What is Compute?
content.data: Think of compute services as the "engine" of the cloud. Just as a car needs an engine to run, your applications need compute resources to execute code, process data, and serve users. Amcloud's cloud provider offers different types of engines, each with its own purpose.

content.title: 1. Virtual Machines (VMs) üíª
content.data: A VM is a virtualized computer running on a physical server in a data center. It's the most flexible compute service, giving you full control over the operating system. You can choose the size of the VM (CPU, RAM), the operating system (Windows, Linux), and configure its networking and storage. Amcloud Scenario: Amcloud's IT team needs to host their main e-commerce website on a reliable and configurable platform. They chose a VM because it gives them complete control. They can install a specific version of a web server (like Apache) and set up custom security patches that meet their compliance requirements. They can also manually scale up the VM's resources when they anticipate high traffic. Analogy: This is like renting a car from a rental agency. You get the whole car (the VM), and you are responsible for everything inside, from the music you play to how you manage the passenger's luggage.

content.title: 2. Containers üì¶
content.data: A container is a lightweight, portable package that includes an application and all its dependencies (libraries, frameworks, and configuration files). Containers are more efficient than VMs because they share the host operating system. This makes them ideal for modern, microservice-based applications. Amcloud Scenario: Amcloud's development team is building a new recommendation engine for their website. Instead of building it as part of the main application, they create it as a separate, small service. They package this service into a container. This ensures that the recommendation engine runs consistently, whether it's on a developer's laptop, in a testing environment, or on a production server in the cloud. They can update the recommendation engine without affecting the rest of the website. Analogy: This is like a pre-packed bento box. Everything you need for your meal is neatly organized and fits in a small, portable box. You don't need to rent an entire kitchen; you just need a surface to place your bento box on.

content.title: 3. Serverless Computing (Functions) üöÄ
content.data: Serverless computing allows you to run your code without provisioning or managing any servers. You simply upload your code, and the cloud provider handles all the server management, scaling, and maintenance. The key benefit is that you only pay when your code is running. Amcloud Scenario: Amcloud's marketing team wants to run a small piece of code that sends an email notification every time a new customer signs up. Instead of using a VM that runs 24/7, they use a serverless function. The function is triggered automatically by the sign-up event. The function only runs for a few seconds to send the email, and Amcloud is only billed for that brief moment of execution, making it extremely cost-effective. Analogy: This is like hiring a contractor to do a single, small task. You just tell them what to do (e.g., "fix this leaky faucet"), and they handle all the tools and logistics. You pay only for the work done, not for the time they spend waiting for another task.

content.title: üîÑ Putting It All Together
content.data: The right compute service depends on your needs: ‚Ä¢ Use a VM for full control and flexibility, especially for traditional applications and legacy systems. ‚Ä¢ Use Containers for portability, efficiency, and microservice architectures. ‚Ä¢ Use Serverless for short-lived, event-driven tasks and to minimize costs by paying only for execution time.

content.title: üìä Compute Services Comparison Table
content.data:
ServiceBest ForKey Advantage
Virtual MachinesLegacy applications, full controlFlexibility
ContainersMicroservices, rapid deploymentPortability & Efficiency
Serverless FunctionsEvent-driven tasks, sporadic workloadsCost-effectiveness (Pay-per-use)

content.data: üëã Welcome back! In our last session, we talked about the "engines" of the cloud. Today, we're going to talk about its "memory" and "filing system": Storage. üíæ

content.title: üîπ 1. Object Storage üñºÔ∏è
content.data: Object storage is used to store unstructured data like images, videos, documents, and backups. Data is stored as "objects" in a flat structure, not in folders like a traditional file system. Each object has a unique identifier and metadata. Amcloud Scenario: Amcloud's e-commerce website has a massive catalog of product images and videos. The marketing team uploads new assets every day. Object storage is the perfect solution for this because it is highly scalable, durable, and cost-effective. Amcloud can store petabytes of data without worrying about server capacity. Examples from Cloud Providers: ‚Ä¢ AWS: Simple Storage Service (S3) ‚Ä¢ Azure: Blob Storage ‚Ä¢ GCP: Cloud Storage Analogy: Think of this as a digital locker room where you can store anything you want. You don't have to worry about where things go; you just put your stuff in a locker and get a key to access it later.

content.alt: amcloud main website's object storage architecture

content.title: üîπ 2. Block Storage üóÑÔ∏è
content.data: Block storage is a type of storage that organizes data into blocks, and each block can be independently controlled and configured. It is the raw data storage that is attached to a virtual machine (VM). This is the traditional way to store data on a hard drive. Amcloud Scenario: Amcloud's main database, which powers its e-commerce website, requires very low latency and high performance. The IT team uses block storage for this database. It is directly connected to their VM, providing the fast I/O performance needed for a high-traffic database. Examples from Cloud Providers: ‚Ä¢ AWS: Elastic Block Store (EBS) ‚Ä¢ Azure: Disk Storage ‚Ä¢ GCP: Persistent Disk Analogy: This is like a single, empty hard drive you plug directly into your computer. You can format it and install an operating system on it, and it gives you direct control over the data.

content.alt: amcloud main website's block storage architecture

content.title: üîπ 3. File Storage üìÅ
content.data: File storage, also known as shared file systems, allows multiple VMs or users to access the same file storage simultaneously. It is based on a traditional hierarchy of files and folders. Amcloud Scenario: The creative design team at Amcloud needs to share large design files, mockups, and videos. Instead of each designer storing a copy on their local machine, they use file storage. Everyone can access the same shared folder, ensuring that they are all working on the most recent version of a file. Examples from Cloud Providers: ‚Ä¢ AWS: Elastic File System (EFS) ‚Ä¢ Azure: Azure Files ‚Ä¢ GCP: Filestore Analogy: This is just like a shared network drive in a traditional office. Everyone with permission can see the same folders and files.

content.alt: amcloud main website's file storage architecture

content.title: üîÑ Putting It All Together
content.data: The right storage service depends on what you're storing and how you need to access it. ‚Ä¢ Use Object Storage for large, unstructured datasets (images, backups). ‚Ä¢ Use Block Storage for high-performance databases and applications. ‚Ä¢ Use File Storage for shared access to files within a team or multiple servers.

content.data:

content.data: üëã Welcome back! In our last sessions, we covered the "engines" (Compute) and "filing systems" (Storage) of the cloud. Today, we're going to talk about its "roads" and "highways": Networking. üåê

üõ£Ô∏è Networking is the fundamental foundation of your cloud environment. It's what connects your servers, your databases, and your users to your applications. It‚Äôs the invisible yet crucial infrastructure that enables everything to work seamlessly.

content.title: üîí I. Virtual Private Cloud (VPC)
content.data:
What is a VPC? A VPC is your own private, isolated virtual data center within the public cloud. You have full control over its IP address range, subnets, route tables, and network gateways. This gives you a secure and isolated space to deploy all your resources.

Amcloud Scenario: When Amcloud's team started their cloud migration, the first thing they did was create a VPC. This VPC became their private space to safely launch their website's web servers and their internal databases, completely isolated from other customers.

Key Concepts:
‚Ä¢ Subnets: A VPC is divided into smaller segments called subnets. They help you organize your resources and control their access.
‚Ä¢ Public Subnet: Resources in this subnet can be accessed from the internet. Amcloud's web servers are placed here so customers can reach the website.
‚Ä¢ Private Subnet: Resources here are completely isolated from the internet and can only be accessed from within the VPC. Amcloud's databases are placed here for maximum security.
‚Ä¢ IP Addressing: Just like in a traditional network, every resource has an IP address. In the cloud, you can have private IPs for internal communication and Elastic IPs or Public IPs for public access.
‚Ä¢ Routing Tables: These tables act like a GPS for your network, telling traffic where to go. They determine if traffic stays within your VPC or goes out to the internet.

content.title: üõ°Ô∏è II. Core Networking Concepts & Security
content.data:
Controlling traffic is key to a secure network. The cloud provides powerful, built-in firewalls.

‚Ä¢ Security Groups: üßë‚Äç‚úàÔ∏è These act as a firewall for your individual instances (like a VM). They control inbound and outbound traffic to and from that specific instance. Think of it as a bouncer at the door of a single club.
‚Ä¢ Network Access Control Lists (Network ACLs): üöß These are stateless firewalls that control traffic for an entire subnet. They provide an additional layer of security. Think of them as a security gate for a whole neighborhood.

content.title: ‚öñÔ∏è III. Load Balancing & Advanced Services
content.data:
Load Balancing: ‚öñÔ∏è A Load Balancer automatically distributes incoming application traffic across multiple servers. This prevents any single server from getting overwhelmed and improves the website's reliability.

Amcloud Scenario: During the Black Friday rush, the Load Balancer directed millions of visitors evenly to a group of web servers, ensuring the site remained fast and responsive. If one server failed, the Load Balancer would instantly stop sending traffic to it.

Connectivity Services: üîó Amcloud uses a Site-to-Site VPN to securely connect its on-premises office to its cloud VPC. For higher bandwidth needs, they could use Direct Connect (AWS), ExpressRoute (Azure), or Cloud Interconnect (GCP).

Content Delivery Network (CDN): üåç A CDN is a globally distributed network of servers that caches content (images, videos) closer to your users.

Amcloud Scenario: When a customer in Paris accesses the Amcloud website, the product images are served from a server in Paris, not from Amcloud‚Äôs main servers in New York, which dramatically speeds up the website.

DNS (Domain Name System): üè∑Ô∏è This service translates human-readable domain names (like amcloud.com) into computer-readable IP addresses. It‚Äôs the phonebook of the internet.

content.title: üåê IV. Putting It All Together: The Amcloud Networking Architecture
content.data:
Here's how Amcloud's network is set up in the cloud:

‚Ä¢ Web Servers: Located in a public subnet and sit behind a Load Balancer to handle user traffic. They are protected by Security Groups.
‚Ä¢ Databases: Placed in a private subnet with no public access. They are only accessible by the web servers, which is a critical security measure.
‚Ä¢ Office Connection: Amcloud's on-premises office network connects to its VPC via a VPN for secure management.
‚Ä¢ Global Performance: A CDN is used to cache static content globally, ensuring a fast user experience for customers everywhere.

content.data: üëã Welcome back! In this session, we're going to dive into a crucial topic for modern cloud development: Containers. üì¶ Containers are a way to package your application and its dependencies into a single, portable unit, ensuring it runs the same way everywhere.

content.title: üß© I. What is a Container?
content.data:
Think of a container as a lightweight, standalone package for your code. It includes everything your application needs to run: the code itself, a runtime (like Python or Node.js), system tools, libraries, and settings. Unlike a virtual machine, a container shares the host operating system's kernel, which makes it much more efficient and faster to start.

Amcloud Scenario: Amcloud's development team used to struggle with "it works on my machine!" issues. A developer would build a new feature, but when the code was moved to a testing environment or a production server, it would break due to missing libraries or configuration differences. By packaging their application into a container, they solved this problem. Now, the container guarantees that the application runs identically on a developer's laptop, in a testing environment, and on a production server.

content.title: ‚ùì II. Why Containers?
content.data:
Before containers, developers would often deploy applications directly onto virtual machines. This led to a series of common problems:

‚Ä¢ Dependency Hell üòµ‚Äçüí´: An application might require a specific version of a library that conflicts with another application on the same VM.
‚Ä¢ Inconsistency üîÑ: The application runs on the developer's laptop but fails in production because the operating systems or environments are slightly different.
‚Ä¢ Slow Deployment üê¢: Setting up a new VM for each application is time-consuming and resource-intensive.

Containers solve these problems by providing an isolated, consistent, and portable environment for your application. They encapsulate everything needed to run, so the application is no longer dependent on the underlying host system.

content.title: ü§ñ III. Container Orchestration
content.data:
While a single container is useful, managing hundreds or thousands of them can be a nightmare. This is where Container Orchestration comes in. An orchestrator is a tool that automates the deployment, scaling, networking, and management of containers.

Amcloud Scenario: Amcloud's e-commerce website is made up of dozens of different services (shopping cart, user authentication, product catalog). Instead of manually launching each container and linking them together, Amcloud uses a managed orchestration service. This service handles all the complexity: it automatically starts new containers when traffic increases, moves them if a server fails, and ensures they can all communicate with each other.

Examples of Cloud Services for Containers:
‚Ä¢ AWS: Amazon Elastic Container Service (ECS) and Amazon Elastic Kubernetes Service (EKS)
‚Ä¢ Azure: Azure Container Instances and Azure Kubernetes Service (AKS)
‚Ä¢ GCP: Cloud Run and Google Kubernetes Engine (GKE)

content.title: üåü IV. The Benefits of Containers
content.data:
‚Ä¢ Portability üöö: Containers can run on any system that has a container engine, whether it‚Äôs a laptop, an on-premises server, or a cloud platform. This makes migration and development much easier.
‚Ä¢ Efficiency ‚ö°: They are lightweight and use fewer resources than traditional VMs. You can run many more containers on a single physical machine.
‚Ä¢ Scalability üìà: It's very easy to scale applications by simply launching more container instances. Orchestration platforms automate this process.
‚Ä¢ Consistency üîÅ: The "package everything" approach ensures that the application behaves the same across all environments, from development to production.

content.title: üè† V. Containers vs. Virtual Machines (VMs)
content.data:
This is a key distinction. While both virtualize a system, they do so at different levels.

FeatureVirtual Machine (VM)Container
AbstractionHardwareOperating System
SizeLarge (GBs)Small (MBs)
Boot TimeMinutesSeconds
IsolationStrong (each has its own OS)Moderate (shares host OS kernel)

Analogy: üè° A VM is like a full house, with its own foundation, walls, and utilities. A Container is like a pre-packaged apartment that you can place inside that house, sharing the same foundation and utilities, but with its own isolated rooms.

content.data: üß™ Lab 3.1: VM + Serverless on AWS Objective: This lab will demonstrate how to deploy an image processing application on a Virtual Machine (VM) and then compare it to a serverless function.

content.title: üìù Prerequisites
content.data:
‚Ä¢ An active AWS account.
‚Ä¢ A web browser.

content.title: üöÄ Step 1: Creating the Virtual Machine (VM)
content.data: We'll start by creating a VM, which is called an EC2 instance in AWS. This is the most basic "compute service." Login: Log in to the AWS Management Console. In the search bar, type EC2 and click the service. Launch an Instance: 1. Click on "Launch instance". 2. Give your instance a name: amcloud-image-processor-vm. 3. Choose an Amazon Machine Image (AMI), for example, the Amazon Linux 2023 AMI (Free Tier). 4. Select an instance type, for example, t2.micro (Free Tier). 5. Under "Key pair (login)", choose an existing key pair or create a new one. Make sure to download and save it! 6. For network settings, choose a default VPC. 7. For security group rules, you can leave the default settings for this lab. 8. Click on "Launch instance". Verification: Wait a few minutes. In the EC2 dashboard, you will see your instance's status change from "pending" to "running." Your VM is now operational, but it isn't doing anything yet.

content.title: ‚ö° Step 2: Creating the Serverless Function (AWS Lambda)
content.data: Next, we'll create a serverless function. This is a completely different approach where you don't manage a server. Login: In the AWS Console search bar, type Lambda and click the service. Create a Function: 1. Click on "Create function". 2. Select "Author from scratch". 3. Give it a name: amcloud-image-processor-function. 4. Choose a "Runtime," for example, Node.js 20.x. 5. For the execution role, select "Create a new role with basic Lambda permissions". 6. Click on "Create function". Function Code: Once the function is created, you can see the default code in the code editor. Imagine that you would insert the image processing code here. You don't have to worry about dependencies or the server that runs it.

content.title: üîç Step 3: Comparison
content.data: VM: You had to choose the machine type, the operating system, and manage the network and security. It is your responsibility to keep this machine up to date. Serverless: You only had to provide your code and the basic configuration. AWS manages the server, the OS, and the scalability. You only pay when your code runs.

content.title: ‚úÖ Conclusion
content.data: For a simple task like image processing, the serverless approach is much more efficient and cost-effective. However, for applications that require total control of the operating system or run continuously, the VM remains a relevant option.

content.title: üßπ Cleanup
content.data: To avoid incurring any unexpected costs, make sure to delete the resources you provisioned during this lab. Terminate the EC2 instance: Go to the EC2 dashboard, select your amcloud-image-processor-vm instance, click on "Instance state", and then "Terminate instance". Delete the Lambda function: Go to the Lambda dashboard, select your amcloud-image-processor-function, and click on "Actions" and then "Delete".

labs.name: Lab 3.2: Static Website Deployment on AWS

content.data: üß™ Lab 3.2: Static Website Deployment on AWS Objective: This lab will demonstrate how to deploy a simple static website using Amazon S3 (Object Storage) and then make it publicly accessible.

content.title: üìù Prerequisites
content.data: ‚Ä¢ An active AWS account. ‚Ä¢ A web browser. ‚Ä¢ A simple HTML file (e.g., index.html).

content.title: üöÄ Step 1: Create an S3 Bucket
content.data: An S3 bucket is where you will store your website's files. The name of the bucket must be globally unique. Login: Log in to the AWS Management Console. In the search bar, type S3 and click the service. Create a Bucket: 1. Click on "Create bucket". 2. Bucket name: Choose a globally unique name (e.g., amcloud-static-website-yourname). 3. AWS Region: Select a region close to you. 4. Leave all other settings at defaults, except for Object Ownership. Select ACLs enabled ‚Üí Bucket owner preferred. 5. Click "Create bucket".

content.title: üìÇ Step 2: Upload Your Website Files
content.data: 1. Navigate to the bucket you just created. 2. Click on "Upload". 3. Click "Add files" and select your index.html file (plus CSS/JS/images if any). 4. Click "Upload".

content.title: üåê Step 3: Enable Static Website Hosting
content.data: By default, the files are not public. Enable static website hosting: 1. Go to your bucket's Properties tab. 2. Scroll down to Static website hosting ‚Üí Edit. 3. Select Enable. 4. Index document: index.html. 5. Error document: error.html (optional). 6. Save changes.

content.title: üîë Step 4: Update Bucket Policy
content.data:
To allow public access, set a bucket policy. 1. Go to the Permissions tab ‚Üí Bucket policy ‚Üí Edit. 2. Paste this JSON policy (replace YOUR_BUCKET_NAME): 
{
    "Version": "2012-10-17",
    "Statement": [
        {
            "Sid": "PublicReadGetObject",
            "Effect": "Allow",
            "Principal": "*",
            "Action": "s3:GetObject",
            "Resource": "arn:aws:s3:::YOUR_BUCKET_NAME/*"
        }
    ]
}
3. Save changes.

content.title: üß™ Step 5: Test Your Website
content.data: 1. Go to Properties ‚Üí Static website hosting. 2. Copy the Bucket website endpoint URL. 3. Paste it in your browser ‚Üí Your site is now live üéâ.

content.title: üßπ Cleanup
content.data: To avoid costs: 1. Empty the bucket: In the Objects tab, click Empty. 2. Delete the bucket: Go back to Buckets list, select your bucket, click Delete, and confirm by typing its name.

üß™ Lab 3.3: VPC Connectivity on AWS Objective: This lab will demonstrate how to create a Virtual Private Cloud (VPC), configure subnets, and establish secure connectivity, mimicking a typical Amcloud setup.

content.title: üìù Prerequisites
content.data:
‚Ä¢ An active AWS account.
‚Ä¢ A web browser.

content.title: üöÄ Step 1: Create a VPC
content.data: The VPC will be our isolated, private network in the cloud. Login: Log in to the AWS Management Console. In the search bar, type VPC and click on the service. Create VPC: 1. In the navigation pane, click on VPCs. 2. Click on Create VPC. 3. Select VPC and more. 4. Name tag auto-generation: Give your VPC a name, e.g., amcloud-main-vpc. 5. IPv4 CIDR block: Use 10.0.0.0/16. 6. Availability Zones (AZs): Choose one or two AZs. 7. Subnets: Configure one public and one private subnet. 8. Click Create VPC.

content.title: üåç Step 2: Launch a Web Server in the Public Subnet
content.data: This EC2 instance represents a web server accessible from the internet. Navigate to EC2: In the AWS Console, type EC2 and go to the dashboard. Launch an Instance: 1. Click on Launch instance. 2. Name: amcloud-web-server. 3. AMI: Choose Amazon Linux 2023 (Free tier). 4. Instance type: t2.micro (Free tier). 5. Key pair: Choose or create a new one. 6. Network settings: ‚Ä¢ VPC: amcloud-main-vpc ‚Ä¢ Subnet: Public subnet ‚Ä¢ Auto-assign Public IP: Enabled 7. Security group: Create a new group. Add inbound rule: allow HTTP (port 80) from 0.0.0.0/0. 8. Click Launch instance.

content.title: üíæ Step 3: Launch a Database in the Private Subnet
content.data: This EC2 instance represents a private database. Launch an Instance: 1. Go back to the EC2 dashboard and click Launch instance. 2. Name: amcloud-database. 3. AMI & type: Amazon Linux 2023, t2.micro. 4. Network settings: ‚Ä¢ VPC: amcloud-main-vpc ‚Ä¢ Subnet: Private subnet ‚Ä¢ Auto-assign Public IP: Disabled 5. Security group: Only allow inbound traffic on database port (e.g., 3306 for MySQL) from the web server‚Äôs security group. This ensures only the web server can connect. 6. Click Launch instance.

content.title: üîç Step 4: Verify Connectivity
content.data: ‚Ä¢ Public Server: From your browser, access the public IP of amcloud-web-server. It should load (empty page). ‚Ä¢ Private Server: Try accessing the database instance‚Äôs IP from your browser ‚Äî it should time out, confirming isolation.

content.title: üßπ Cleanup
content.data: To avoid charges, delete resources after the lab: 1. Terminate Instances: In EC2, select both amcloud-web-server and amcloud-database, then Instance state ‚Üí Terminate. 2. Delete VPC: In VPC dashboard, select amcloud-main-vpc ‚Üí Actions ‚Üí Delete VPC. Make sure dependent resources are removed first.

üß™ Lab 3.4: Build and Push a Docker Image to Amazon ECR This document provides a simple, step-by-step guide to containerizing a basic web application and deploying it to Amazon Elastic Container Registry (ECR).

content.title: üöÄ Step 1: Create an ECR Repository
content.data: 1. Navigate to the AWS Management Console. 2. Search for ECR and select Elastic Container Registry. 3. Click Create repository. 4. Give your repository a name (e.g., amcloud-app-repo) and click Create repository.

content.title: üõ†Ô∏è Step 2: Create a Local Docker Image
content.data:
1. Create a new working directory on your local machine. 2. Inside this directory, create a file named Dockerfile. 3. Also, create a file named index.html in the same directory. index.html content: 
<h1>Hello, Amcloud!</h1>
<p>This page is served from a Docker container.</p>
Dockerfile content: 
FROM nginx:latest
COPY index.html /usr/share/nginx/html
EXPOSE 80
4. Open your terminal, navigate to your working directory, and build the Docker image: 
docker build -t amcloud-web-app .

content.title: üîë Step 3: Authenticate Docker to ECR
content.data: 1. Go back to the AWS ECR console and click on your newly created repository. 2. Click View push commands in the top-right corner. 3. Copy the first command (the get-login-password command) and run it in your terminal. This will authenticate your Docker client for 12 hours.

content.title: üì§ Step 4: Push the Image to ECR
content.data:
1. From the same View push commands window, copy and run the second command (docker tag). Example: 
docker tag amcloud-web-app:latest 123456789012.dkr.ecr.us-east-1.amazonaws.com/amcloud-app-repo:latest
2. Copy and run the third command (docker push) to push your local image to the ECR repository. Example: 
docker push 123456789012.dkr.ecr.us-east-1.amazonaws.com/amcloud-app-repo:latest
Once complete, your Docker image will be stored in ECR, ready for deployment with services like ECS or EKS.

content.title: üìã Copy Code Support
content.data: <script>document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded',function(){document.querySelectorAll('.copy-btn').forEach(function(btn){btn.addEventListener('click',function(e){var targetId=btn.getAttribute('data-copy-target');var code=document.getElementById(targetId);if(code){var text=code.innerText||code.textContent;navigator.clipboard.writeText(text).then(function(){btn.textContent='Copied!';setTimeout(function(){btn.textContent='Copy';},1200);});}});});});</script>
